generally title this article shall be known and may be cited as the natural gas code of the city    182001 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning aga means american gas association approved  as to materials workmanship and types of construction means approval by the gas inspector or authorized utility personnel as the result of investigation inspections or tests conducted by the inspector or by reason of accepted principles or tests by nationally recognized authorities category i vented appliance means an appliance that operates with a nonpositive vent static pressure and with a vent gas temperature that avoids excessive condensate production in the vent combustible material means walls floors ceilings shelves or other parts of a building constructed of wood composition or paper including walls constructed of wooden studding lath and plaster csaus means canadian standards association  united states replaces aga logo and symbols flue liner means a liner to be installed in a masonry chimney used to vent natural gas burning equipment up to 350000 british thermal units per hour gama means gas appliance manufacturers association gas inspector means the manager or assistant manager of the gas operations department of the cedar falls utilities gas appliance means a fixture or apparatus manufactured and designed to use natural gas as a fuel gas piping means any run of pipe or fittings that is used to convey natural gas installed on any premises or in any building but shall not include any portion of the service piping gas piping system means any arrangement of gas piping supplied by one meter house piping means that portion of the gas piping leading from the outlet side of the gas meter and any gas piping connected to and extending beyond that portion of the system ias means international approval services formerly aga manufactured home means a structure transportable in one or more sections that is eightbody feet or more in width or 40body feet or more in length in the traveling mode or when erected on site is 320 cubic feet or more which is built on a chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities including the plumbing heating air conditioning and electrical systems contained therein minor repairs means adjustment of appliances replacement of parts repairing leaks and similar work nfpa means national fire protection association protected combustible material means combustible material protected with a metal shield extending over an area exposed to the effects of heat from a gas appliance so formed that an air space of not less than one inch is maintained between such shield and the combustible materials in lieu of such air space fireproof material not less than onequarter inch in thickness or other approved equally effective insulating material may be used between such metal shield and any combustible material service piping means the piping between the street gas main and the gas meter type b vent means a vent for venting listed gas appliances with draft hoods and other category i gas appliances listed for use with type b gas vents vent connection means a pipe designed to convey the products of combustion from a gas appliance to a flue liner    182001 conflicting provisions  subjects not covered by article the provisions of this article shall not be applicable where federal or state laws or rules and regulations thereof preempt any provision subjects not regulated by this article or interpretation of this article should be referred to national fire protection association nfpa 54 national fuel gas edition    182001 administration of article a the gas inspector shall administer this article b hud approved manufactured homes are under federal jurisdiction and exempt from portions of this article    182001 gas inspector a the general manager of utilities shall appoint a qualified gas inspector who shall be confirmed by the utility board of trustees b the inspector shall hold office during the pleasure of the utilities board and until a successor is appointed by the general manager and is confirmed by the utilities board of trustees c the inspector will be and will constitute the authority for administration of this article d the inspector or utility personnel authorized by the inspector shall inspect and supervise all work done or authorized to be done under the provisions of this article    182001 bond  guarantee of service a it shall be unlawful for any person except as otherwise provided in this article to install alter or repair any gas piping gas vent or gas burning appliances until the person has first obtained a surety bond in the amount of $100000 which must be approved by the inspector and held on file in the gas operations department at the cedar falls utilities b the bond shall be accompanied by a guarantee of future 24hour on call service on all equipment to be installed this guarantee shall be limited to a period of two years from the date of installation of such equipment c it shall be the responsibility of the person to keep a current bond on file in the gas operations department at the cedar falls utilities if the bond expires no further installation permits shall be issued to the individual or company until a valid bond is issued and filed as provided herein    182001 general inspections a upon completion of the installation of any gas piping or gas appliance and prior to the use thereof the permit holder shall notify the gas inspector or authorized utility personnel that such piping or appliances are ready for inspection b the inspections shall be made by the gas inspector or authorized utility personnel who shall either approve that portion of the work as completed or shall notify the permit holder wherein the work fails to comply with this article the permit holder must notify the utilities when all work is completed for a final inspection    182001 authority to disconnect appliances or piping the gas inspector and authorized utility personnel are hereby authorized to disconnect any gas appliance or gas piping which shall be found not to conform to the requirements of this article  which may be found defective and in such condition as to endanger life or property  or which was not authorized by the utilities where such disconnection has been made a notice shall be attached to such appliance or gas piping which shall state that the appliance or piping has been disconnected together with the reasons such notice shall not be removed nor shall the appliance or gas piping be reconnected until authorized by the inspector also see section 7109c    182001 certificate of inspection  smoke tests a no gasfired equipment shall be placed in permanent operation without prior inspection and a certificate of inspection issued by authorized utility personnel a white tag signifies compliance b whenever a smoke test or other approved testing method is required the test shall be performed in the presence of authorized utility personnel c if the final piping inspection shows the piping has been found to comply with the provisions of this article a certificate of inspection shall be issued a white tag signifies compliance d if the inspection of the gasfired equipment shows that it complies with the provisions of this article a certificate of inspection shall be issued a white tag signifies compliance    182001 connecting or turning on service a it shall be unlawful for any person except an authorized utility employee to turn on or reconnect gas service or a meter in or on any premises b it shall be unlawful to turn on or connect gas on or in any premises unless all outlets are properly and securely connected to appliances or capped or plugged    182001 gas piping a all gas piping must be black steel galvanized pipe or corrugated stainless steel tubing and fittings sizing of gas lines must be adequate to deliver gas supply to all appliances connected to piping without creating a pressure drop that will prevent the appliances from operating at their intended efficiency b all such pipe shall either be new or shall previously been used for no other purpose than conveying gas and shall be clear and free from cutting burrs and defects in structure or threading and shall be thoroughly brushed and scale blown c gas piping should be run exposed wherever possible where gas piping is installed in concealed areas such as walls ceilings etc where corrosion is no problem welded standard pipe corrugated stainless steel tubing and fittings or threaded fittings all with the proper air test of ten pounds for 15 minutes may be used authorized utility personnel must inspect the installation d when gas piping is buried in an exterior location either wrapped or coated pipe welded and air tested or polyethylene pipe authorized by the gas inspector must be used in general no gas piping should be installed under a cement floor or slab if this becomes necessary wrapped black steel pipe or polyethylene pipe laid inside a gas tight duct with the duct vented to the outside must be used the installer must furnish all necessary equipment and gauges for air testing pipelines belonging to the customer it will be permissible to use plastic piping approved for natural gas for outside underground lines only e a shutoff valve must be provided in the pipeline ahead of each gas appliance installed ahead of the union or appliance connector the shutoff valve on a furnace must be installed outside the furnace cabinet where accessible exceptions must be approved by the gas inspector or authorized utility personnel approved flexible appliance connectors may be used to connect portable appliances such as ranges dryers etc flexible connectors in commercial applications will be required to be double walled or approved for commercial applications standard residential connectors will not be allowed in commercial applications f flexible connectors will not be allowed to pass wall ceiling floor or cabinet on movable appliances only one flexible connector per appliance will be allowed g a drip leg shall be required on furnaces and water heaters only manufactured homes are exempt from this rule h copper or aluminum tubing shall not be used for gas lines or connections except where it is part of the appliance design i pipe compound or thread tape shall be used on all fittings and of a make recommended by an approved source from its manufacturer as being approved for both lp and natural gas j all gas piping carrying a gas pressure in excess of nine inches water column shall be welded and air tested all gas piping over two inches in size shall be welded and air tested the air test shall be no less than 150 percent the proposed working pressure but not less than ten psig the air test will be for 15 minutes without pressure drop k threaded pipe and fittings may be tested with an air test instead of the usual soap bubble test on all joints the test is ten pounds for 15 minutes cedar falls utilities personnel shall witness all air tests referenced in this article and reserve the right to require a longer time for any air tests based upon pipe size length of the pipe runs and other conditions l gas piping may be installed in concealed locations with no access in accordance with the following rule when gas piping that is to be concealed is being installed  only elbows tees caps and couplings shall be used m manufactured homes may be connected to the gas meter with solid iron pipe or a dormont type outdoor flex connector approved for manufactured home use n any natural gas piping going block or concrete walls must be sleeved with plastic pipe to protect from deterioration    182001 installation of used appliances used gas appliances may be reinstalled when in the opinion of the gas inspector or authorized utility personnel such appliances may be used without danger to life or property used furnaces shall require a smoke test or equivalent test witnessed by authorized utility personnel prior to installation    182001 approval of appliances gas appliances shall be csaus approved or approved by an equivalenttesting laboratory a rating plate shall be attached in such a manner as to be easily read where gas appliances are installed that have not been so approved they will be subject to the judgment of the gas inspector as to their fitness for use alteration or protection before their use may be required in order to meet the gas inspectors safety requirements    182001 water heaters a water heaters shall not be installed in bathrooms or in rooms less than 600 cubic feet in size unless adequate air intake and ventilation is provided all water heaters must be provided with a positive automatic shutoff valve that will not allow gas to pass main burner in the event of a pilot outage all water heaters must be equipped with an approved automatic opening and closing temperature and pressure relief valve all water heaters installed in a garage area shall be at least 18 inches from floor level to the burner b all water heaters must be vented and the vent must be so installed regardless of horizontal or vertical height or lengths that all products of combustion are carried to the outside air where there is a flue liner from a furnace or a space heater the water heater must be vented into this liner or into a separate flue or vent water heaters should not be vented into oil burner stacks c water heaters installed in manufactured homes shall be marked for manufactured home use    182001 space heating appliances a gas warm air furnaces boilers and unit heaters or any type of space heater shall be csausapproved or approved by an equivalent testing laboratory clearance from combustible materials shall be according to manufacturers recommendations or as required by the gas utility b all heating equipment installed in a garage area shall be at least 18 inches from floor level to the burner c minimum sheet metal clearance for gas fired hot air furnaces shall be as follows or if this is not possible the furnace shall be satisfactorily insulated with fireproof material 1 plenums on forced air furnaces with a maximum high limit setting up to 250 degrees fahrenheit shall have a clearance of two inches from combustible material and a oneinch clearance on heat runs three feet out from the plenum 2 gravity furnaces where a limit higher than 250 degrees fahrenheit is maintained shall have adequate clearance from combustible material or be so insulated that they will be considered by an authorized gas inspector to be safe 3 all gasfired appliances requiring natural venting must have a draft diverter properly designed to the manufacturers specifications d where a space heater furnace conversion burner or any other gas fired appliance is installed in a confined area such as a utility room or similar area an adequate supply of combustion air must be supplied from other than the living quarters area an outside air opening one inch larger than the combined venting area of connected equipment will be deemed adequate e any house built or remodeled after 1973 must have adequate combustion and dilution air to provide for the proper safe operation of the natural gas furnace fresh air taken from outside or from a ventilated attic shall be installed preferably into the cold air return by the furnace installer f no circulating air supply inlet for blower type warm air furnaces shall be located where there is a possibility of reversing the venting picking up fumes objectionable odors or flammable vapors g where exhaust fans are installed in a building that can cause the gas vents to reverse downdraft or spill when the gas appliance is burning the appliance must be shielded or protected or an induced draft fan must be installed so that it will function properly or more outside air must be introduced h all furnaces shall be provided with an approved electrical disconnect located within reach of the furnace    182001 operating instructions for appliances a operating instructions for appliances are to be left on the job by the installer b instructions furnished by the manufacturer outlining procedures as follows should be attached to or near the installation 1 instructions for the proper manner of operating the main shutoff gas valve and pilot valve and the proper sequence for lighting 2 instructions outlining the proper sequence for turning off gas burners and closing gas main and auxiliary valves    182001 venting a forced draft or exhaust systems may only be installed in areas for which they have been designed by the manufacturer or where conditions make it appropriate b all gas appliances shall be vented unless otherwise approved by an authorized utility inspector some exceptions are domestic ranges gas and air torches and dryers all gas venting should be provided with ample vertical height and a horizontal length as short as possible c appliance air andor fresh air must be installed at least ten feet from gas meter setups appliance exhaust should not be vented directly below windows or above gas meter setups manufacturer installation instructions will be used on exhaust installations exceptions to the provision set forth in this subsection must be approved in advance by the gas inspector    182001 chimneys a for heating equipment flue liners must be used where total gas burning input is more than 50000 or less than 350000 btus per hour b installation of new furnaces that no longer use the chimney going up house and leave only the water heater in the chimney must have a properly sized chimney to accommodate the water heater only even if this requires a smaller liner to be installed in the existing chimney c the flue pipe should extend chimney wall to the inner face of the liner but not beyond and should be firmly cemented to masonry the flue pipe should be sealed into the chimney liner or attached to the type b vent by use of a tee or elbow d flue connections from two or more appliances should not enter opposing or adjacent sides of the chimney or type b vent at the same level flue pipes must never be connected into a fireplace chimney flue    182001 chimney flues a where gas vents are used to discharge gases directly to the outside without the use of masonry chimneys type b insulated vents may be used the manufacturers instructions for clearance from combustible materials and clearance plates must be used b a csaus or equivalent testing laboratory approved draft hood must be used on all gasfired appliances requiring venting except incinerators where a field control must be used as provided by the manufacturer c the draft hood in all cases must be located at a point level with or higher than the top of the highest flue passage in the appliance in order to be able to develop full rating on some heating appliances it will be necessary to install the draft hood as high as possible this is true of revertible flue furnaces where it is specifically recommended that the relief opening of the draft hood is at least one foot higher than the highest point of the flue passage for conversion of revertible flue type appliances it is recommended that a small opening or passage of not less than one inch pipe size be provided between the top of the highest point in the flue passage of the appliance and its vertical flue pipe d if there is a bypass the bypass shall be opened slightly and locked in position e all draft hoods shall be installed in the position for which they were designed in no case shall a draft hood be installed in a false ceiling or in a separate room from the heating system or in any manner that will permit a difference in pressure between the draft hood relief opening and the combustion air supply    182001 installation of gasfired equipment in sleeping quarters a only properly vented space heaters may be installed in sleeping quarters ample fresh air intake or area must be available b all gas furnaces space heaters or boilers or any gas appliance where pressure fluctuation may interfere with its proper operation must be equipped with a pressure regulator all such appliances must also be equipped with an automatic pilot controlled safety shutoff that will shut the gas off to the main burner in the event of pilot failure    182001 approved flue liners approved flue liners are as follows vitrified steel pipe stainless steel pipe lap joint vitrified clay pipe flexible stainless steel type b liners or butt to butt tile use of the latter is limited to manufacturers recommended use only type b vents shall be installed as close as possible to the appliance to meet gama regulations    182001 starting up and checking out gasfired equipment a all gas appliances shall be properly assembled and checked out by the installer the appliance shall then be shut off and an authorized utility inspector notified for its checkout and inspection b all permits shall be taken out in advance of any installation and the authorized utility inspector shall be notified when the installation is completed this applies to owners who do their own installing as well as to contractors c when the appliance installation or piping has passed the authorized utility inspectors inspection it will be tagged with an acceptance tag if the work or appliance is not satisfactory it will be tagged with a caution or rejection tag and may either be left in service or shut off depending on the safe condition of the appliance the installer will be notified either by the inspector at the job or by phone regarding the failure of the installation to pass inspection an authorized utility inspector will shut off service to the appliance or the gas meter if the installer fails to correct all defects in the appliance or piping    182001 burners firing 500000 btus per hour or larger input minimum requirements for burners firing 500000 btus per hour or larger input are as follows 1 all such burners must be equipped with approved electronic controls 2 main burner shutoff valves shall be an approved type with handles permanently attached 3 main burner shutoff valves shall be rated to close against a minimum of 15 pounds per square inch gas pressure in three seconds or less 4 where gas pressure exceeds 15 pounds per square inch in the gas utility mains the safety shutoff valve shall be rated to close against these pressures 5 electrical wiring shall provide for closing of this valve on a power failure or interruption b action from any safety limit switches c pilot failure 6 two electrically operated gas valves on the main burner gas lien are required one shall be the input control valve and the other the safety shutoff valve and each shall be so constructed that it will perform its specific job 7 a oneeighthinch pipe tap is to be provided with a nipple and cap in the manifold for connecting a manifold pressure gauge for test purposes 8 a high and low gas pressure switch shall be installed downstream from the input valve and set as close to manifold pressure as possible without causing nuisance shutdowns when used with an automatic reset type valve this control must be equipped with a manual reset feature when used with a manual reset type safety shutoff valve this control may be either the automatic reset type or the manual reset type    182001 general burner firing a all burners must be adjusted for input size by fixed orifice and pressure regulator adjustment with the manual valve in the wideopen position for final checkout a manual pilot shutoff valve and a pilot safety shutoff valve must be installed b a low water cutoff with an automatic feeder must be provided on all steam boilers adequate protection to ensure automatic filling or shutdown of the burner must be provided for gas fired hot water boilers when a pressure or temperature control is used as an operating controller an additional high pressure or high temperature safety control must be installed to serve as the high limit to shut burners off in the event of overpressurizing or too high a temperature c a double acting properly sized field control with a stack temperature switch must be installed  or if a diverter is used a temperature switch must be installed at the bottom of the draft diverter on this size of appliance this switch must be wired into the safety shutoff valve d wiring and operating diagrams shall be placed on the job as close to appliances as is practical e specially fired gas burning appliances not complying with the requirements of this section shall not be connected to the gas utility piping system unless individual clearance has been made with the gas inspector the appliance must be something other than a boiler furnace water heater etc it must be proven safe for its particular use to the satisfaction of the inspector and be provided with whatever controls are required to make it a safe appliance to operate    182001 proximity of appliances to combustible materials a gas appliances so constructed that the burners are not shielded by metal or other approved insulating material shall not be located within 12 inches of any combustible material b all gas appliances except floor and wall furnaces so constructed that metal shields or other approved insulating materials are an integral part of their construction shall not be installed so as to permit such metal shields or other approved insulating materials to be within six inches of combustible material or within three inches of protected combustible material unless approved by csaus or an equivalent testing laboratory for less clearance c gas appliances having open flames such as gas plates and ranges shall not be installed within three feet of any combustible ceiling material d the top and side walls of a warm air gas furnace shall be not less than six inches from protected or unprotected combustible material unless approved by csaus or an equivalent testing laboratory for less clearance e every floor of combustible construction under a gas burning warm air furnace shall be covered with onequarter inch of fireproof millboard or other equivalent fire protective material the floor protection shall project at least 12 inches beyond all sides of the furnace or to the furnace enclosure the floor covering may be omitted on a wood floor under any gas burning warm air furnace if the combustion chamber is not less than 24 inches from the floor and is separated by a metal plate or shield unless approved by csaus or an equivalent testing laboratory for less clearance    182001 incinerators a all gasfired incinerators shall be csaus should be laid in a trench from the building to the light or grill and deep enough so that it will not be broken by normal activity in the area where it is installed    182001 fireplace logs gas logs division 2  prohibition on discharge of stormwater and groundwater to city sanitary sewer discharge of stormwater or groundwater into city sanitary sewer system the discharge of water from any roof surface ground sump pump footing tile or from any other natural precipitation source into the city sanitary sewer collection system has the potential to cause damage to property and to overload the city wastewater collection conveyance and treatment system such discharge may result in the backup of sewage into living quarters of residential dwellings or into other buildings or structures in the city thereby creating a potential public health hazard and potentially exceeding the capacity of the city wastewater collection conveyance and treatment system therefore the city finds that it is essential to the maintenance of public health safety comfort and welfare to the minimization of damage to property and to the maintenance of the functioning and capacity of the city wastewater collection conveyance and treatment system that the provisions of this division be strictly enforced since was adopted on  this prohibited the discharge of stormwater from any dwelling building or other structure into the citys sanitary sewer system the provisions of this division shall apply to every dwelling building or other structure in the city for the construction of which a city building permit was issued after     542015   762015 restrictions and definitions no water from any roof surface ground sump pump footing tile or from any other natural precipitation source shall be discharged into the city sanitary sewer system any dwelling building or other structure subject to the provisions of this division which because of the infiltration of water into basements crawl spaces and the like require a seepage collection system a beaver drain or any sump pump system to discharge water shall have a permanentlyinstalled discharge line which shall not at any time connect to or discharge such stormwater into the city sanitary sewer system for purposes of this division a permanent installation shall be one which provides for a yearround discharge connection to the city subdrainstorm sewer system if there is no city subdrainstorm sewer system available to the property the surface discharge point shall be located no closer than ten feet from any property line or as otherwise approved by the director of community development or his designee such discharge line shall consist of a rigid discharge line inside the structure without valving or quick connections for altering the path of discharge and if connected to the city subdrainstorm sewer system shall include a check valve    542015   762015 sump pump and rigid pipe  method of installation a any such discharge line to impact neighboring properties or any city street sidewalk or rightofway c where a sump pit exists in any such dwelling building or other structure subject to this division it shall have a pump day until completed with the least possible obstruction to the thoroughfares occupied b no building being moved shall be stored on the streets of the city unless authorized by the building official no granted the applicant must sign a statement assuming liability for any damage to persons and property including property of the city and indemnify the city for any claims against the city arising out has been notified by certified mail at least ten days prior to the proposed action  bond the applicant for a license required by this division shall file with his application a bond with an approved ordinances of the city relating to house moving and that the applicant will pay to the city to the city utilities or to any person all costs incurred or all damages for injuries to person or property derived this division being for the protection of the public health and safety    8232004 secs 73537377  reserved article vii  cross connection control containment provisions purpose the purpose of this article is to safeguard potable water supplies by preventing backflow into public water systems    6231997 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning administrative authority means for the purpose of this section the administrative authority shall be the board of trustees of the municipal water utility of the city for backflow prevention assemblies for containment and the city council of the city for backflow prevention by isolation acting persons or agencies they shall designate air gap water distribution means an air gap water distribution is the unobstructed vertical distance free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet conveying potable water to the flood level rim of any tank vat or fixture approved backflow prevention assembly for containment means a backflow prevention assembly which is listed by the university of southern californiafoundation for cross connection control and hydraulic research as having met the requirements of ansiawwa standard c510 current revision double check valve backflow prevention assemblies or ansiawwa standard c511 current revision reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assemblies for containment the listing shall include the limitations of use based on the degree of hazard the backflow prevention assembly must also be listed by the international association of plumbing and mechanical officials approved backflow prevention assembly for containment in a fire protection system means a backflow prevention assembly to be used in a fire protection system which meets the requirements of factory mutual research corporation fm and underwriters laboratory ul and the requirement of the fire code and the building code of the city in addition to the requirements in the definition of the term approved backflow prevention assembly for containment devices sized smaller than 212 inches which have not been listed by underwriters laboratory ul and tested by factory mutual research corporation fm may be allowed if they meet the requirements of the fire code and the building code of the city auxiliary water supply means any water supply on or available to the premises other than the water purveyors approved public water supply such as but not limited to a private well pond or river containment means a method of backflow prevention which requires the installation of a backflow prevention assembly at the water service entrance contamination means an impairment of the quality of the potable water which creates an actual hazard to the public health or spread of disease by sewage industrial fluids or waste also defined as high hazard cross connection means any actual or potential connection or arrangement physical or otherwise between a potable water supply system and any plumbing fixture or tank receptacle equipment or device it may be possible for nonpotable used unclean polluted and contaminated water or other substance to enter into any part of such potable water system under any condition customer means the owner operator or occupant of a building or property which has a water service from a public water system or the owner or operator of a private water system which has a water service from a public water system degree of hazard means the rating of a cross connection or water service which indicates if it has the potential to cause contamination or pollution double check valve backflow prevention assembly means a backflow prevention device consisting of two independently acting internally loaded check valves four properly located test cocks and two isolation valves high hazard cross connections means a cross connection which may cause an impairment of the quality of the potable water by creating an actual hazard to the public health or spread of disease by sewage industrial fluids or waste isolation means a method of backflow prevention in which a backflow prevention assembly is located at the crossconnection rather than at the water service entrance low hazard cross connection means a cross connection which may cause an impairment of the quality of potable water to a degree which does adversely and unreasonably affect the aesthetic qualities of such potable waters for domestic use multiple family residential units means a building designed to be used as residential occupancy for three or more dwelling units each having separate plumbing facilities pollution means an impairment of the quality of the potable water to a degree which does not create a hazard to the public health but which does adversely and unreasonably affect the aesthetic qualities of such potable waters for domestic use the term pollution is defined as low hazard potable water means water which is satisfactory for drinking culinary and domestic purposes and meets the requirements of the health authority having jurisdiction privately owned customer water system piping means water service line pipes and plumbing fixtures connected to the public water system of the city which are extended to the customers property and into the customers building for service to the customer and are regulatory controlled by which is defined in the city reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly means a backflow prevention device consisting of two independently acting internally loaded check valves a different pressure relief valve four properly located test cocks and two isolation valves registered backflow prevention assembly technician means a person who is registered by the state of to test or repair backflow prevention assemblies and report on the condition of those assemblies singleunit dwelling means a structure containing one dwelling unit thermal expansion means volumetric increase of water due to heating resulting in increased pressure in a closed system water service means depending on the context water service is the physical connection between a public water system and a customers building property or private water system or the act of providing potable water to a customer    6231997 administrative authority a for the purpose of this article only the administrative authority shall be the board of trustees of the municipal water utility of the city for backflow prevention assemblies for containment and the city council of the city for backflow prevention by isolation acting persons or agencies they shall designate b the administrative authority shall have the right to enter with the consent of the customer or upon the basis of a suitable warrant issued by a court of appropriate jurisdiction any property to inspect for possible crossconnections c the administrative authority may approve training programs for backflow prevention assembly technicians and register backflow prevention assembly technicians who successfully complete an approved training program d the administrative authority may collect fees for the administration of this program fees shall be established by resolution of the board of trustees of the municipal water utility and city council from time to time e the administrative authority shall maintain records of cross connection hazard surveys and the installation testing and repair of all backflow prevention assemblies for containment purposes    6231997 new water service a plans shall be submitted to the administrative authority for review of all new water services to determine size and degree of hazard b the administrative authority shall determine the type of backflow prevention assembly required for containment based on the degree of hazard c the administrative authority shall require the installation of the appropriate backflow prevention assembly for containment before the initiation of water service    6231997 existing water services a upgrades of existing water services shall be treated as new water services for the purpose of this section b the administrative authority shall publish and make available to each customer a copy of the standards used to determine the degree of hazard c after publication of the standards the administrative authority shall notify customers whose premises are classified as singleunit residential in writing of the provisions of this article and shall require compliance therewith d within six months after publication of the standards customers whose premises are not classified as singleunit residential shall complete and return to the administrative authority a crossconnection hazard survey to be used to determine the type of containment device e the administrative authority shall on the basis of information received from customers or gathered premises investigations or surveys determine the type of backflow prevention assembly required for containment based on the degree of hazard f within the time frame specified in writing by the administrative authority the customer shall install a backflow prevention assembly for containment required by the administrative authority g for existing water services the administrative authority may inspect the premises to determine the degree of hazard when the high hazard cross connections are found the administrative authority shall at its sole discretion 1 develop a schedule of compliance which the customer shall follow  or 2 terminate the water service until a backflow prevention assembly for containment required by the administrative authority has been installed h failure of the administrative authority to notify a customer that they are believed to have a high hazard cross connection and that they shall install backflow prevention assemblies for containment in no way relieves a customer of the responsibility to comply with all requirements of this section    6231997 customer a the customer shall be responsible for ensuring that no cross connections exist without approved backflow protection within his premises starting at the point of service from the public potable water system b the customer shall at his own expense cause installation operation testing and maintenance of the backflow prevention assemblies required by the administrative authority c the customer shall ensure the administrative authority is provided with copies of records of the installation and of all tests and repairs made to the backflow prevention assembly on the approved form within 15 days after testing andor repairs are completed d in the event of a backflow incident the customer shall immediately notify the municipal utility of the city and the city building inspection division of the incident and take immediate action to confine the contamination or pollution    6231997 required backflow prevention assemblies for containment  water services a an air gap or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly is required for water services having one or more cross connections which the administrative authority classifies as high hazard b an approved double check valve assembly is required for water services having no high hazard crossconnections but having one or more cross connections which the administrative authority has classified as low hazard c every water service which is required to install a backflow prevention assembly at point of entry will be required to follow section 6083 of the uniform plumbing code at time of installation    6231997 required backflow prevention assemblies for containment fire protection systems a a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly shall be installed on all new and existing fire protection systems which the administrative authority determines to have any of the following 1 direct connections from public water mains with an auxiliary water supply on or available to the premises for pumper connection 2 interconnections with auxiliary supplies such as reservoirs rivers ponds wells mills or other industrial water systems 3 use of antifreezes or other additives in the fire protection system 4 combined industrial or domestic with high hazard and fire protection systems supplied from the public water mains only with or without gravity storage or pump suction tanks 5 any other facility connection or condition which may cause contamination b a double check valve assembly shall be required for all other fire protection systems the double check valve shall be required on all new systems at the time of installation and on existing systems at the time that they are upgraded c submittal of proposed backflow prevention devices to the administrative authority does not relieve the designer or sprinkler contractor of the responsibility of submitting plans including backflow prevention devices to the fire marshal for approval    6231997 registration of backflow prevention assembly technician a backflow prevention assembly technician registered by the state shall include his registration number on all correspondence and forms required by or associated with this article    6231997 registered backflow prevention assembly technician noncompliance a the registration of a technician will be recommended for revocation or suspension for a period of up to two years for noncompliance with this article further action will be taken as prescribed by law to prevent further noncompliance b any of the following conditions constitute noncompliance 1 improper testing or repair of backflow prevention assemblies 2 improper reporting of the results of testing or of repairs made to backflow prevention assemblies 3 failure to meet registration requirements 4 related unethical practices    6231997 installation of backflow prevention assemblies a installation of backflow prevention assemblies shall be made by a licensed and bonded plumbing contractor of the city with proper permits b the required backflow prevention assemblies for containment shall be installed in horizontal plumbing immediately following the meter or as close to that location as deemed practical by the administrative authority in any case it shall be located upstream from any branch piping installation at this point does not eliminate the responsibility of the customer to protect the water supply system from containment or pollution between the backflow prevention assembly and the water main c reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed so as to be protected from flooding d reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assemblies shall not be installed in underground vaults or pits e all backflow prevention assemblies shall be protected from freezing those devices used for seasonal services may be removed in lieu of being protected from freezing  however the devices must be reinstalled and tested by a registered backflow prevention assembly technician prior to service being reactivated f if hot water is used within the water system thermal expansion shall be provided for when installing a backflow prevention assembly for containment g provisions shall be made to convey the discharge of water from reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assemblies to a suitable drain h no backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed in a place where it would create a safety hazard such as but not limited to over an electrical panel or above ceiling level i if interruption of water service during testing and repair of backflow prevention assemblies for containment is unacceptable to the customer another backflow prevention assembly sized to handle the temporary water flow need during the time of test or repair should be installed in parallel piping all such installations shall be at the customers expense j all backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed so that they are accessible for testing as stated in section 603 of the uniform plumbing code k all shutoff valves conform with the current edition of the manual of cross connection control university of southern california requirements for either ball or resilient seat gate valves at the time of installation ball valves shall be used on assemblies installed in piping two inches and smaller and resilient seat gate valves on assemblies installed in piping larger than two inches    6231997 testing of backflow prevention assemblies a testing of backflow prevention assemblies shall be performed by a registered backflow prevention assembly technician the costs of test required in subsections b e of this section shall be borne by the customer b backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested upon installation and tested and inspected at least annually c backflow prevention assemblies which are in place but have been out of operation for more than three months shall be tested before being put back into operation backflow prevention assemblies used in seasonal applications shall be tested before being put into operation each season d any backflow prevention assembly which fails a periodic test shall be repaired or replaced when water service has been terminated for noncompliance the backflow prevention assembly shall be repaired or replaced prior to the resumption of water service backflow prevention assemblies shall be retested by a registered backflow prevention assembly technician immediately after repair or replacement e the administrative authority may require backflow prevention assemblies to be tested at any time in addition to the annual testing requirement f the registered backflow prevention assembly technician shall report the successful test of a backflow prevention assembly to the customer and to the administrative authority on the form provided by the administrative authority within 15 days of the test g the administrative authority may require at its own cost additional tests of individual backflow prevention assemblies as it shall deem necessary to verify test procedures and results    6231997 repair of backflow prevention assemblies a all repairs to backflow prevention assemblies shall be performed by registered backflow prevention assembly technicians b the registered backflow prevention assembly technician shall not change the design material or operational characteristics of a backflow prevention assembly during repair or maintenance and shall use only original manufacturer replacement parts c the registered backflow prevention assembly technician shall report the repair of a backflow prevention assembly to the customer and to the administrative authority on the form provided by the administrative authority within 15 days of the repair the report shall include the list of materials or replacement parts used d any time fire services are discontinued for a period of time longer than necessary to test the device the tester is required to notify the fire marshals office that the fire services are shut off for repairs    6231997 customer noncompliance the water service may be discontinued in the case of noncompliance with this section noncompliance includes but is not limited to the following 1 refusal to allow the administrative authority access to the property to inspect for cross connections 2 removal of a backflow prevention assembly which has been required by the administrative authority 3 bypassing of a backflow prevention assembly which has been required by the administrative authority 4 providing inadequate backflow prevention when crossconnections exist 5 failure to install a backflow prevention assembly which has been required by the administrative authority 6 failure to test andor properly repair a backflow prevention assembly as required by the administrative authority 7 failure to comply with the requirements of this article    6231997 secs 73927410  reserved article viii  mechanical code title this article shall be known as the city of appeals shall have no authority to waive requirements of this code 2 an appeal to the city council of any ruling of the board shall be made by filing a written notice of such appeal with the city clerk within ten days from the date of the ruling being appealed the council shall give the appellant and the board a minimum of five days written notice by certified mail of the date time and location of hearing of said appeal all interested persons shall be given the opportunity to be heard at such hearing and the city council may affirm modify or overrule the action of the board based upon the evidence submitted before the city council 13 subsections 1092 are deleted in their entirety 14 the following new section 1110 mechanical inspector  is added to chapter 1 1110 mechanical inspector 1111 office created  appointment  qualifications 1 the office of the mechanical inspector within the inspection services division of the department of community development of the city is hereby created and such inspector is hereby authorized directed and empowered to inspect any and all buildings or structures public and private and as provided in this article to condemn and order removed or remodeled and put into proper and safe condition for safety to life and property all mechanical systems equipment and related structures and to control the disposition and arrangement of such equipment and systems so that persons and property shall not be in danger therefrom the terms authority having jurisdiction and mechanical inspector as used in this article or in the code adopted by this article refer to the same person and are used interchangeably 2 the mechanical inspector shall be appointed by the director of community development after recommendation of the building official and shall be directly responsible to the building official 3 the appointee shall a be qualified in the mechanical trade and shall have at least ten years of practical experience in the mechanical trade or five years of experience as a mechanical inspector or in lieu of such experience shall have a combination of trade school practical experience and inspection experience considered by the city council as being suitable for minimum requirements and shall have had two years of practical mechanical experience  b be possessed of such executive ability as requisite for the performance of required duties and have thorough knowledge of the standards materials and methods used in the installation of mechanical equipment  c be well versed in improved methods of construction for safety to persons and property the statutes of the state relating to mechanical work and any orders rules and regulations issued by authority thereof and in the uniform mechanical code  and d as a minimum hold a current state journeyman mechanical license or shall be required to pass an examination for journeyman mechanical prior to appointment by the community development department 1112 supervision by building official the mechanical inspector shall work fully under the supervision and jurisdiction of the building official and take all orders and perform any duties or services that may be designated by the building official pertaining to mechanical inspections or other related duties 1113 conflict of interest it shall be unlawful for the mechanical inspector or assistant mechanical inspectors to engage in the business of the sales installation or maintenance of mechanical equipment either directly or indirectly and they shall have no financial interest in any concern engaged in such business in the city at any time while holding the office provided for in this division 1114 records 1 the mechanical inspector shall keep or cause to be kept records of all permits issued and inspections made and all other business of his office the records shall be available to the public 2 the mechanical inspector shall keep an accounting record for the billing of permit fees faithful performance of all duties required of such contractor by any ordinances rules and regulations of the city it shall be a further condition of said certificate of insurance that the obligor will hold the city harmless from any and all damages sustained by reason of neglect or incompetency on the part of such contractor his agents or employees in the performance of the work done under a license or permit issued upon the filing of said certificate  said certificate of insurance shall be issued by december 31 of each year and shall be refiled on or before said date for each subsequent building or structure is located to the horizontal property regime established by iowa b the declarant shall file the declaration of the horizontal property regime with the city clerk of the city at least 60 days before the declaration is recorded in the office of the county recorder to enable the city to establish that the existing building or structure meets the applicable building code requirements of the city as specified in iowa b20 and as described in this article    2232009 filing of asbuilt plans in compliance with all requirements of iowa b and this article the declarant shall submit to the city clerk at the time of filing of the declaration a full and exact copy of asbuilt plans of the existing structure in sufficient detail to allow the city building official to determine whether the existing structure meets the building code requirements of the city which are in effect as of the date of the proposed conversion of the existing structure to the horizontal property regime together with the applicable condominium conversion fee in such amount as shall be established from time to time by resolution of the city council    2232009 compliance with city building code requirements in order to satisfy the requirements of this article the existing building or structure which is to be submitted to the horizontal property regime must meet all city building code requirements which are in effect as of the date of filing of the declaration with the city clerk    2232009 inspection of structure upon the filing of such a declaration with the city clerk the city clerk shall promptly furnish a copy of the declaration including the as built plans to the city building official the city building official shall promptly conduct all necessary site and building inspections to determine whether the existing structure meets all city building code requirements described in this article    2232009 issuance of certificate of compliance or noncompliance within 60 days of the date of filing of such declaration with the city clerk the city building official shall either 1 issue to the declarant a certificate of compliance of the existing structure if the existing structure meets all city building code requirements described in this article  or 2 issue to the declarant a certificate of noncompliance of the existing structure stating with specificity wherein the existing structure does not meet the city building code requirements described in this article    2232009 secs 74497479  reserved article x  conversion to housing cooperative conversion of shall be held in the city on the first tuesday after the first monday in november of each oddnumbered year and elective officers shall thus be chosen biennially to succeed officers whose terms expire at  noon on january 1 which is not a sunday or legal holiday following a regular city election  runoff elections the city does hereby elect to hold a runoff election when a position for an office within the city is unfilled because of a failure of a sufficient number of candidates to receive a majority vote in a regular city election all as provided in iowa 6 and 3769 as amended  special municipal elections special municipal elections shall be held at such places in each ward in the city as the council shall direct and at the time and in the manner provided by law  disturbing election  interfering with election officers no person shall disturb any election by loud noise fighting or otherwise or hinder voters from voting by obstructing the passage to and from the ballot box or do any act to delay or disturb the officers of an election in the discharge of their duties  fire prevention and protection article i  in general secs 91918  reserved article ii  fire code international and burning of leaves and grass clippings definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning bonfire is the open burning of cut trees vegetation other than leaves or grass clippings or lumber with a total fuel area from three to five feet in diameter and from two to five feet in height garbage means all organic refuse created in the preparation of food or decayed or spoiled animal or vegetable food from any source other than leaves or grass clippings health hazard means a condition which is likely to result in death or injury to or illness of humans recreational fire means the burning of materials other than rubbish leaves or grass clippings where the fuel being burned is not contained in an incinerator outdoor fireplace barbecue grill or barbecue pit and which consists of a total fuel area of three feet or less in diameter and two feet or less in height for pleasure religious ceremonial cooking or similar purposes rubbish means all combustible nonorganic waste material such as papers paper goods cardboard and similar materials originating from ordinary household or business operations    5272003   7262004 penalty for violation of article any violation of this article is a municipal infraction punishable as provided in section 19    5272003 presumption regarding violations any fire ignited or burning in violation of any of the provisions of this article whether on private property or on public property adjacent to private property shall be presumed to be set by or with the permission of the owner of the private property and shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption in any proceeding charging a violation of the provisions of this article for the purposes of this article an owner is defined as the titleholder or contract purchaser or tenant in possession of any private property located within the city    5272003 authority to prohibit fires the fire chief or his designee may prohibit any and all bonfires recreational fires and fires of any other type upon complaint or when atmospheric or local conditions within the city create a fire hazard or a health hazard    5272003 burning prohibited  exceptions no person shall kindle or burn or maintain a bonfire on any open privately owned land except as follows 1 an approved incinerator is a metal incinerator with a maximum capacity of 30 gallons constructed of fireresistive material including a lid and containing ventilation holes no larger than 112 inches in diameter 2 when an incinerator is used for burning as authorized by this article the incinerator must be covered at all times by a lid and is to be placed when so used not less than 20 feet from any building 3 fires in incinerators and outdoor bonfires other than recreational fires authorized by this article shall be permitted only between the hours of  noon and darkness unless a special permit is first obtained from the fire chief or his designee darkness for the purposes of this article shall be determined to commence when the photoelectric controlled street lights in the city are turned on 4 except as otherwise provided in section 959 fires for the open burning of plant material other than leaves or grass clippings grown on the premises or deposited thereon by the elements shall be permitted only between the hours of  noon and darkness the fires must not be less than 20 feet from any building and must be contained within a fire pit incinerator or other confined area for the purposes of this section plant material includes branches from all plants or trees not exceeding 112 inches in diameter but excludes leaves and grass clippings 5 all burning authorized by this article shall be supervised by a competent person at all times and shall not be left unattended until the fire is completely extinguished    5272003   7262004 demolition of buildings and clearing of land  burning for agricultural maintenance or ecological purposes a whenever any person within the city limits proposes to raze or demolish a building or destroy trees and brush for the purpose of clearing land the person shall first request in writing permission to do so the request shall be submitted to the office of the fire chief within 72 hours after the receipt of the request the fire chief or his designee shall make an inspection of the property to determine the feasibility of such request after the inspection the fire chief or his designee shall in writing either grant or deny the request and if the request is granted the chief or his designee shall state the conditions under which the proposed burning shall be permitted in addition before any building is burned approval of the building official must be obtained b whenever any person within the city limits proposes to burn vegetation other than leaves or grass clippings on 1 land that is used predominantly for agricultural purposes  or 2 land that must be burned for maintenance or ecological reasons such as gardens prairie preserves ditches groves woodlands fence rows drainage channels or railroad rightsofway  the person shall first request in writing permission to do so the request shall be submitted to the office of the fire chief within 72 hours after the receipt of the request the fire chief or his designee shall make an inspection of the property to determine the feasibility of such request after the inspection the fire chief or his designee shall in writing either grant or deny the request and if the request is granted the chief or his designee shall state the conditions under which the proposed burning shall be permitted the chief or his designee shall consider the atmospheric environmental and other conditions present to determine if such burning may be permitted without creating a fire hazard or a health hazard    5272003 other permitted fires the following types of fires are permitted within the city limits as long as such fires do not involve the burning of leaves or grass clippings and to the extent such types of fires are not inconsistent with the provisions of this article 1 fires used solely for the cooking of food 2 recreational fires subject to the following requirements a recreational fires shall not be conducted within 20 feet of a structure or combustible material unless contained in a barbecue pit conditions which could cause a fire to spread to within 20 feet of a structure shall be eliminated prior to ignition  b buckets shovels garden hoses or a fire extinguisher with a minimum 4a rating shall be readily available for use  c the fire shall be constantly attended by a person knowledgeable in the use of fire extinguisher equipment required by subsection 2b of this section until such fire has been extinguished  and d the fire chief is authorized to require that recreational fires be immediately discontinued if such fires are determined by the fire chief to constitute a hazardous condition 3 fires set for the purpose of bona fide instruction or training of public or private employees in the method of firefighting 4 bonfires subject to the following requirements a bonfires shall not be conducted within 50 feet of a structure or combustible material conditions which could cause a bonfire to spread to within 50 feet of a structure shall be eliminated prior to ignition  b buckets shovels garden hoses or a fire extinguisher with a minimum 4a rating shall be readily available for use  c the fire shall be constantly attended by a person knowledgeable in the use of fire extinguisher equipment required by subsection 4b of this section until such fire has been extinguished  and d the fire chief is authorized to require that bonfires be immediately discontinued if such fires are determined by the fire chief to constitute a hazardous condition    5272003   4 commissioner shall be two years the mayor shall designate a chairperson and vicechairperson from among the commissioners vacancies occurring on the board caused by resignation or otherwise shall be filled by the mayor and approved by the council for the unexpired term all members of the board shall serve without compensation except necessary expenses including travel expenses incurred in the discharge of their duties d a majority of the commissioners shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of conducting business and exercising such powers as delegated to them by the city council as well as for all other purposes action may be taken by the commission upon a vote of a majority of the commissioners present unless in any case the bylaws shall require a larger number such board may adopt rules bylaws and regulations governing its organization and procedures as may be deemed necessary and subject to the approval of the city council e the board of commissioners shall be responsible initially to undertake and carry out studies and analyses of the housing needs and of the meeting of such needs and to make the results of such studies and analyses available to the public as well as article ii  minimum rentalhousing code division 1  generally title  applicability the regulations set out in this article together with the codes referred to in sections 112 and 114 shall be known as the cedar falls minimum rentalhousing  and may be cited as such to the extent any of the provisions of the codes adopted by reference in section 112 and in section 1141 6 are inconsistent with the provisions of this article then the provisions of this article shall apply and the conflicting provisions of such other codes shall not apply to this article 1431 12182017 applicability of article the provisions of this article shall apply to all buildings or portions thereof within the jurisdiction of the city which are nonowner occupied and which are used or intended to be used for human occupancy unless otherwise specified except as otherwise provided in this article such occupancy in existing buildings may be continued as provided in international residential section r1027 and international building section 1026 as adopted by the city additionally all accessory buildings or structures are hereby subject to all applicable sections regarding health safety and maintenance thereof as contained in the city building code nothing contained in this article is intended to apply to persons under 18 years of age nor the familial status of any person 1 exception 1 newly constructed buildings for which permits have been issued and which have passed final inspections all in accordance with the applicable provisions of the codes referred to and incorporated by reference in section 114 shall be exempt from the requirements of sections 11116 inclusive and section 11127 the final decision as to whether such newly constructed buildings meet the requirements of this exception 1 shall be made by the fire chief or the fire chiefs designee 2 exception 2 existing buildings for which permits have been issued and which have passed final inspections all in accordance with the applicable provisions of the codes referred to and incorporated by reference in section 114 shall be exempt from the requirements of sections 11116 inclusive and section 11127 the final decision as to whether such existing buildings meet the requirements of this exception 2 shall be made by the fire chief or the fire chiefs designee 1432 12182017 purpose of article the purpose of this article is to provide minimum standards to safeguard life or limb health property and public welfare by regulating and controlling the use occupancy and maintenance of all residential rental buildings and related structures within the city 1433 12182017 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning whenever the terms dwelling dwelling unit boardinghouse roominghouse or premises are used in this article they shall be construed as though they were followed by the words or any part thereof acceptable or approved means in compliance with the provisions of this article accessory structure means a structure which is not used or intended to be used for living or sleeping by human occupants appurtenance means that which is directly or indirectly connected or accessory to some other structure basement means the lowest story of the building just beneath the main floor wholly or partly underground bath means a bathtub or shower stall connected with hot and cold water lines boardinghouse means a building other than a hotel or other overnight lodging facility where for compensation lodging and meals are provided by the building owners or managers for resident boarders with meals for all resident boarders provided in a central kitchen facility within said building said boarding facility shall be distinctive from transient lodging facilities such as hotels beds and breakfasts other overnight lodging facilities or public eateries residents within said boardinghouse facility shall be accommodated with weekly monthly or yearly tenant agreements or leases communal means used or shared by or intended to be used or shared by the occupants of two or more rooming units or two or more dwelling units condominium means a dwelling unit which is in compliance with the requirements of iowa b as amended cooperative means a dwelling unit which is in compliance with the requirements of iowa b as amended court means an open unoccupied space which is more than 50 percent enclosed by buildings dining room means a habitable room used or intended to be used for the purpose of eating but not for cooking or the preparation of meals dwelling means any building or structure containing one or more units used intended or designed for occupancy by persons including any attached appurtenances dwelling multiple means any structure containing three or more dwelling units dwelling singleunit means a structure containing one dwelling unit dwelling twounit means a structure containing two dwelling units dwelling twounit conversion means a structure that was originally constructed as a singleunit dwelling but which was subsequently converted to a twounit dwelling dwelling unit means any building room or group of adjoining rooms providing complete independent living facilities for one or more persons including permanent provisions for living sleeping eating cooking and sanitation extermination means the control and elimination of insects rodents or other pests by eliminating their harborage places by removing or making inaccessible materials that may serve as their food by poisoning spraying fumigating or trapping or by any other recognized and legal pest elimination methods approved by the inspector garbage means animal or vegetable waste resulting from the handling preparation cooking or consumption of food and shall also mean combustible waste material the term garbage also includes paper rags cartons boxes wood rubber leather tree branches yard trimmings and other combustible materials habitable room means a room or enclosed space having a minimum of 70 square feet of total floor area within a dwelling unit or rooming unit used or intended to be used for living sleeping cooking and eating purposes excluding bathrooms toilet rooms pantries laundries foyers corridors closets storage spaces and stairways infestation means the presence within or around a dwelling of any insects rodents or other pests in such quantities as would be considered unsanitary inspection followup means one of a number of reinspections of a dwelling unit following an initial inspection designed to determine and achieve compliance with deficiencies noted in the initial and any other followup inspections inspection initial means a periodic inspection of a dwelling unit conducted to determine compliance with the provisions of this article whether initiated by the inspector or by written complaint inspector means the official of the city delegated the responsibility to administer the provisions of this article together with his duly authorized representatives or agents kitchen means a habitable room used or intended to be used for cooking and the preparation of meals kitchenette means a food preparation area of not less than 40 square feet lavatory means a handwashing basin which is connected to both hot and cold water lines which is separate and distinct from a kitchen sink minimum rental housing occupancy permit means a document issued by the city evidencing authority premises owner means any person who has control of any dwelling dwelling unit or roominghouse by virtue of a contractual interest in or legal or equitable title to the dwelling dwelling unit or roominghouse an owner who has sold the premises on contract but retains legal title shall not be deemed an owner under this article person means any individual firm corporation association partnership trust or estate plumbing means any or all of the following supplied facilities and equipment gas pipes gasburning equipment water pipes garbage disposal units waste pipes toilets sinks lavatories bathtubs showers water heating devices catchbasins drains vents and other similar supplied fixtures together with all connections to water sewer or gas service premises means a lot plot or parcel of land including all buildings thereon refuse means waste materials except human waste including garbage rubbish ashes and dead animals rooming unit means any habitable room or group of adjoining habitable rooms located within a dwelling and forming a single unit with facilities which are used or intended to be used primarily for living and sleeping a rooming unit shall have a bath and toilet facilities available for exclusive use by the occupant roominghouse means an owneroccupied or manageroccupied single dwelling unit wherein individual sleeping rooms are provided to not less than three
